terms.definition: A vessel containing hydraulic fluid under pressure used to operate BOP equipment.
A BOP component that uses a rubber element to seal around any size pipe, kelly, or open hole.
Pressure maintained on the annulus during well control operations, typically applied through the choke.
A cement plug placed in the wellbore using the balanced plug method where tubing is raised as cement is placed.
An envelope of one or more barrier elements that prevents flow from a source.
A single component that cannot prevent flow by itself but contributes to a barrier.
Bottom Hole Assembly - the lower portion of the drillstring including bit, collars, and tools.
Bottom Hole Pressure - total pressure at a given depth in the well.
BOP rams designed to close on open hole when no pipe is in the well.
BOP rams that can cut through drillpipe and seal the wellbore.
Uncontrolled flow of formation fluids from the wellbore.
Blowout Preventer - pressure control equipment installed on the wellhead.
Forcing fluids down the wellbore against formation pressure without circulation.
Steel pipe cemented in the wellbore to provide structural integrity and isolation.
An adjustable valve used to control flow rate and back pressure during well control.
High-pressure line connecting the BOP stack to the choke manifold.
Pressure required to circulate fluid through the well at a given rate.
Gas that enters the wellbore during connections due to loss of ECD.
Rock fragments produced by the drill bit and circulated to surface.
Drilling Gas - background gas level while drilling.
Well kill method using two circulations: first to circulate kick out, second to circulate kill mud in.
Equivalent Circulating Density - effective mud weight including friction losses while circulating.
Emergency Disconnect System - system to disconnect from subsea BOP in emergency.
Equivalent Mud Weight - formation pressure expressed as equivalent density.
Stopping circulation to observe whether the well is flowing.
Final Circulating Pressure - pump pressure when kill mud reaches the bit.
Test to determine the maximum pressure a formation can withstand without fracturing.
Drilling fluid containing entrained gas, reducing density.
Closing BOP with pumps off and no choke line flow.
High Pressure High Temperature - wells exceeding defined pressure/temperature thresholds.
Pressure exerted by a column of fluid due to its height and density.
Initial Circulating Pressure - pump pressure at start of kill circulation.
Formation fluids entering the wellbore (gas, oil, or water).
International Well Control Forum - certification body for well control training.
A square or hexagonal pipe that connects the rotary table to the drillstring.
Entry of formation fluids into the wellbore due to underbalanced conditions.
Maximum kick volume that can be safely handled without fracturing the weakest formation.
High-pressure line used to pump kill fluid into the wellbore.
Drilling fluid weighted to balance formation pressure.
Mud density required to balance formation pressure with no surface pressure.
Leak-Off Test - test to determine formation fracture pressure.
Lower Marine Riser Package - upper portion of subsea BOP stack.
Loss of drilling fluid into the formation.
Maximum Allowable Annular Surface Pressure - maximum pressure before formation breakdown.
Upward movement of gas in a shut-in well due to buoyancy.
Managed Pressure Drilling - drilling technique using surface back pressure for well control.
Density of drilling fluid, typically expressed in ppg or sg.
Condition where wellbore pressure exceeds formation pressure.
Condition where buoyancy effects make drillstring appear lighter than actual weight.
BOP rams designed to seal around specific pipe size.
Increase in mud pit volume indicating influx.
Pressure of fluids within formation pore spaces.
Pressure While Drilling - downhole pressure measurement tool.
Rotating Control Device - pressure containment device allowing rotation.
Conduit connecting floating rig to subsea BOP or wellhead.
Remotely Operated Vehicle - underwater robot for subsea operations.
Shut-In Casing Pressure - pressure on annulus after shutting in on kick.
Shut-In Drillpipe Pressure - pressure on drillpipe after shutting in on kick.
Reduced pump rate used for well control operations.
Running pipe into a well under pressure when pipe weight is less than wellbore pressure force.
Closing BOP with choke initially open to limit water hammer.
Standpipe Pressure - pressure at the standpipe manifold.
Subsurface Safety Valve - downhole valve providing well barrier in production wells.
Running pipe into or out of a well under pressure when pipe weight exceeds pressure force.
Pressure reduction caused by pulling pipe upward.
Pressure increase caused by running pipe downward.
Additional mud weight above required for overbalance, compensating for swab effects.
True Vertical Depth - vertical distance from reference point to target.
Condition where wellbore pressure is less than formation pressure.
Well control technique using periodic fluid bleed-off to control gas migration.
Well kill method using single circulation of kill weight mud.
Pressure surge caused by sudden valve closure or pump stop.
Well Barrier Element - single component of a well barrier.
Equipment installed at surface providing structural support and pressure containment.
IADC well control certification program.
